title: Rufus Wainwright
text:

[[Kate McGarrigle]] | relatives = [[Martha Wainwright]] (sister)
[[Lucy Wainwright Roche]] (half-sister) | module = {{Infobox musical artist|embed = yes | background = solo_singer | instrument = {{hlist|Vocals|keyboards|guitar}} | genre = {{flatlist| *[[Baroque pop]]{{cite web|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2007/05/baroque-pop-idol/|title=Rufus Wainwright: Baroque Pop Idol|website=Motherjones.com|access-date=August 12, 2018}} *[[operatic pop]]{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/classical/reviews/rufus-wainwright-prima-donna-sadlerrsquos-wells-london-1943418.html|title=Rufus Wainwright Prima Donna, Sadler's Wells, London|website=Independent.co.uk|date=October 23, 2011|access-date=August 12, 2018}} *[[indie pop]]{{cite web|last=Atkinson |first=Katie |url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2012/04/03/rufus-wainwright-helena-bonham-carter-out-of-the-game/ |title=Helena Bonham Carter stars in Rufus Wainwright video | The Music Mix | EW.com |website=Music-mix.ew.com |date=April 3, 2012 |access-date=March 25, 2014}} *[[rock music|rock]]{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/apr/28/classicalmusicandopera3|title=Wainwright to switch from rock to opera|first=Sean|last=Michaels|date=April 28, 2008|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=August 12, 2018}} *[[opera]]{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/apr/13/prima-donna-review|title=Prima Donna - Opera review|first=Andrew|last=Clements|date=April 13, 2010|website=the Guardian|access-date=August 12, 2018}} }} | occupation = | years_active = 1988–present | label = [[Geffen Records|Geffen]], [[DreamWorks Records|DreamWorks]] | website = {{URL|http://www.rufuswainwright.com/}} }} }} '''Rufus McGarrigle Wainwright''' (born July 22, 1973) is a Canadian{{cite magazine|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/online/daily/2010/12/qarufus-wainwright-on|title=Q&A: Rufus Wainwright on Liza, Lulu, and Proposing|magazine=Vanity Fair|access-date=August 8, 2013}} singer, songwriter, and [[composer]].{{cite news|url=http://www.lejournaldespaysdenhautlavallee.ca/culture/2015/7/21/un-moment-unique-avec-rufus-wainwright-.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150727031630/http://www.lejournaldespaysdenhautlavallee.ca/culture/2015/7/21/un-moment-unique-avec-rufus-wainwright-.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=July 27, 2015 |first1=Geneviève |last1=Lamothe |date=July 21, 2015 |language=fr |title=Un moment unique avec Rufus Wainwright |newspaper=Le Journal des Pays-d'en-Haut La Vallée |access-date=August 12, 2015 }} He has recorded 10 studio albums and numerous tracks on compilations and film soundtracks. He has also written two classical operas and set [[Shakespeare's sonnets]] to music for a theatre piece by [[Robert Wilson (director)|Robert Wilson]]. Wainwright's [[Rufus Wainwright (album)|self-titled debut album]] was released through [[DreamWorks Records]] in May 1998. His second album, ''[[Poses (album)|Poses]]'', was released in June 2001. Wainwright's third and fourth studio albums, ''[[Want One]]'' (2003) and ''[[Want Two]]'' (2004), were repackaged as the [[double album]] ''[[Want (Rufus Wainwright album)|Want]]'' in 2005. In 2007, Wainwright released his fifth studio album ''[[Release the Stars]]'' and his first live album ''[[Rufus Does Judy at Carnegie Hall]]''. His second live album ''[[Milwaukee at Last!!!]]'' was released in 2009, followed by the studio albums ''[[All Days Are Nights: Songs for Lulu]]'' (2010) and ''[[Out of the Game]]'' (2012). The double album ''[[Prima Donna (Rufus Wainwright album)|Prima Donna]]'' (2015), was a recording of his [[Prima Donna (opera)|opera of the same name]]. His ninth studio album ''[[Take All My Loves: 9 Shakespeare Sonnets]]'' (2016), featured nine adaptions of [[Shakespeare's sonnets]]. Rufus' 10th studio album, ''[[Unfollow the Rules]]'', was released on July 20, 2020. Wainwright is the son of musicians [[Loudon Wainwright III]] and [[Kate McGarrigle]], and the older brother of singer [[Martha Wainwright]]. ==Life and career== ===Early years=== Wainwright was born in [[Vancouver]], to folk singers [[Kate McGarrigle]] and [[Loudon Wainwright III]].{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p2160/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Loudon Wainwright III|website=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=October 27, 2006}}{{cite web|url=http://player.nos.nl/index.php/media/play/tcmid/tcm:5-567376/|title=Dutch Public TV news interview with Rufus Wainwright at statue of Peter Stuyvesant|publisher=[[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting]]|access-date=September 16, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120223190603/http://player.nos.nl/index.php/media/play/tcmid/tcm:5-567376/|archive-date=February 23, 2012|url-status=dead}} His parents divorced when he was three, and he lived with his mother in [[Montreal]] for most of his youth. His father is a [[Lineal descendant|descendant]] of [[Peter Stuyvesant]], the 17th century [[Dutch people|Dutch]] [[governor]] of [[New Amsterdam]], later [[New York (state)|New York]]. Wainwright has dual US and Canadian citizenship.{{cite web|access-date=November 19, 2008|url=http://www.charleston.net/news/2008/jan/12/singer_readies_solo_concerts27185/|title=Singer readies for solo concerts|last=Righi|first=Len|work=[[The Post and Courier]]|date=January 12, 2008|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120729020538/http://www.charleston.net/news/2008/jan/12/singer_readies_solo_concerts27185/|archive-date=July 29, 2012}} He attended high school at the [[Millbrook School]] in New York (which would later inspire his song "Millbrook"), and later briefly studied piano at [[McGill University|McGill]] in Montreal. He began playing the piano at age six, and started touring at age 13 with "The McGarrigle Sisters and Family", a folk group featuring Rufus, his sister [[Martha Wainwright|Martha]], his mother Kate, and aunt [[Anna McGarrigle|Anna]]. His song "I'm a-Runnin'", which he performed in the film ''[[Tommy Tricker and the Stamp Traveller]]'' at the age of 14, earned him a nomination for a [[10th Genie Awards|1989]] [[Genie Awards|Genie Award]] for [[Genie Award for Best Achievement in Music - Original Song|Best Original Song]].{{cite web|access-date=March 17, 2007|url=http://www.academy.ca/hist/history.cfm?categid=17&shownum=10&winonly=0&awards=1&rtype=5&curstep=4|title=10th Genies – Best Original Song|publisher=[[Genie Awards]]|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061010105252/http://www.academy.ca/hist/history.cfm?categid=17&shownum=10&winonly=0&awards=1&rtype=5&curstep=4|archive-date=October 10, 2006}} He was nominated for a [[Juno Awards of 1990|1990]] [[Juno Award]] for [[Juno Award for Artist of the Year|Most Promising Male Vocalist of the Year]].{{cite web|access-date=February 23, 2011|url=http://junoawards.ca/database/artist-summary/?artist_name=rufus+wainwright|title=Juno Awards Database|publisher=[[Juno Award]]s|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706184430/http://junoawards.ca/database/artist-summary/?artist_name=rufus+wainwright|archive-date=July 6, 2011}} Wainwright identified as gay while a teenager.{{cite web|title=The Wainwright Stuff|first=Randy|last=Shulman|work=[[Metro Weekly]]|date=March 11, 2009|access-date=March 18, 2008|url=http://www.metroweekly.com/feature/?ak=659}} In 1999, he told ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' that his father recognized his homosexuality early on. "We'd drive around in the car, he'd play '[[Heart of Glass (song)|Heart of Glass]]' and I'd sort of mouth the words, pretend to be [[Blondie (band)|Blondie]]. Just a sign of many other things to come as well."{{Cite news|title=Rants & Raves – Brief Article|work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]|date=December 7, 1999|access-date=October 25, 2011|url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1589/is_1999_Dec_7/ai_57828696#continue|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013184120/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1589/is_1999_Dec_7/ai_57828696#continue|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 13, 2007}} Wainwright later said in another interview that his "mother and father could not even handle me being gay. We never talked about it really."{{cite magazine|title=Wainwright Feared Being HIV Positive After Rape|magazine=[[Contactmusic]]|date=February 22, 2005|access-date=October 20, 2006|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/new/xmlfeed.nsf/mndwebpages/wainwright%20feared%20being%20hiv%20positive%20after%20rape}} Wainwright became interested in opera during his adolescent years, and the genre strongly influences his music. (For instance, the song "Barcelona" features lyrics from the [[libretto]] of [[Giuseppe Verdi]]'s opera, ''[[Macbeth (opera)|Macbeth]]''.) During this time, he became interested in [[Édith Piaf]], [[Al Jolson]], and [[Judy Garland]]. As a youth he trained at [[Interlochen Center for the Arts|Interlochen Arts Camp]], studying classical music.{{Cite web|url=https://www.mlive.com/entertainment/grand-rapids/2012/06/qa_with_rufus_wainwright_singe.html|title=Q&A with Rufus Wainwright: Singer/songwriter talks about getting married, Interlochen and new album 'Out of the Game'|date=June 28, 2012|website=Mlive.com|access-date=July 11, 2020}} At age 14, Wainwright was [[sexually assaulted]] in London's [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]] after picking up a man at a bar. In an interview years later, he described the event: "I said I wanted to go to the park and see where this big concert was going on. I thought it was going to be a romantic walk in the park, but he raped me and robbed me afterwards and tried to strangle me". Wainwright states that he survived only by pretending to be an [[epilepsy|epileptic]] and faking a seizure. He has been reported to have stated that he remained celibate for five or seven years after the incident, and eventually became promiscuous.{{cite web|title=Rufus Wainwrights Rape Tragedy|website=FemaleFirst.co.uk|date=March 1, 2005|access-date=January 11, 2010|url=http://www.femalefirst.co.uk/music/musicnews/Rufus+Wainwright-3238.html}}{{cite web|first=Richard|last=Goldstein|title=A Torch Song Named Desire|work=[[The Village Voice]]|date=August 25, 1999|access-date=October 20, 2006|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/news/9934,goldstein,7854,1.html|archive-date=June 18, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080618095756/http://www.villagevoice.com/news/9934,goldstein,7854,1.html|url-status=dead}} ===Rise to fame, debut album=== Through weekly shows at Cafe Sarajevo, Wainwright was on the Montreal club circuit and eventually cut a series of demo tapes produced by [[Pierre Marchand]], who later produced Wainwright's album ''[[Poses (album)|Poses]]''. The resulting tapes impressed his father Loudon, who passed them on to his friend [[Van Dyke Parks]]. Parks sent the recordings to [[Lenny Waronker]], the [[DreamWorks Records]] executive who eventually signed Wainwright to his label. The singer moved to New York City in 1996, performing regularly at [[Club Fez]]. He relocated to Los Angeles that year and began his first studio album, 1998's ''[[Rufus Wainwright (album)|Rufus Wainwright]]''. Waronker paired Wainwright with producer [[Jon Brion]], and the two spent most of 1996 and 1997 making the record. Wainwright recorded 56 songs in total, on 62 rolls of tape. The sessions cost $700,000. Wainwright's self-titled debut received critical acclaim; ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' recognized it as one of the best albums of the year, and named the singer "Best New Artist" of the year. Wainwright was nominated for four awards by the Gay & Lesbian American Music Awards, including Album of the Year, Pop Recording of the Year and Video of the Year, and won for Best New Artist.{{cite web|access-date=November 1, 2008|url=http://www.queermusicheritage.us/awards.html|title=The Gay & Lesbian American Music Awards|publisher=Queer Music Heritage}}{{cite web|access-date=November 1, 2008|url=http://www.rainbowsuite.com/Rainbow%20Suite%20Records/rknight/glama.htm|title=3rd Annual Gay/Lesbian American Music Awards Nominees Announced|publisher=Rainbow Suite}} ''Rufus Wainwright'' won a [[GLAAD Media Award]] for Outstanding Music Album and a Juno Award for Best Alternative Album.{{cite web|access-date=October 1, 2008|url=http://www.qrd.org/qrd/media/television/1999/GLAAD.announces.nominees.for.annual.media.awards-01.20.99|title=GLAAD Announces Nominees of 10th Anniversary Media Awards|publisher=Queer Resources Directory|date=January 20, 1999}} However, commercial success of the album was limited; the debut failed to chart in any country, though he ranked No.24 on ''Billboard'''s [[Top Heatseekers]] chart.{{cite web|access-date=October 13, 2008|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p181528/charts-awards|pure_url=yes}}|title=Rufus Wainwright US Heatseekers Charting|website=[[AllMusic]]}} In 1996 Wainwright toured the UK as "Special Guest" of [[Kate & Anna McGarrigle]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2012}} He toured with [[Sean Lennon]] in 1998[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1998-07-12/news/9807120318_1_chicago-cultural-center-rufus-wainwright-first-bow Rock: Sean Lennon and Rufus Wainwright are blessed and...]. Chicago Tribune, July 12, 1998. and began his first headline tour later that year. In December 1998, he appeared in a [[Gap (clothing)|Gap]] commercial directed by [[Phil Harder]], performing [[Frank Loesser]]'s "What Are You Doing New Year's Eve?".Kirk Lake, ''There Will Be Rainbows'', position 2104 of the ebook In March 1999, Wainwright began a headlining tour in [[Hoboken, New Jersey|Hoboken]], New Jersey.{{Cite web|title = Rufus Wainwright Kicks Off Tour, Explains Video Cameos|url = http://www.mtv.com/news/1435154/rufus-wainwright-kicks-off-tour-explains-video-cameos/|website = MTV News|access-date = November 20, 2015}} ===''Poses'' and struggle with addiction=== Wainwright lived in the [[Hotel Chelsea|Chelsea Hotel]] in New York City for six months, during which he wrote most of his second album. On June 5, 2001, Wainwright's second album, [[Poses (album)|''Poses'']], was released to critical acclaim but limited sales. The album ranked No.117 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and No.1 on the Top Heatseekers chart.{{cite web|access-date=October 13, 2008|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=rufus wainwright|chart=all}}|title=Rufus Wainwright American Charting – Billboard 200|website=Billboard.com}} ''Poses'' won a GLAAD Media Award for Outstanding Music Album and a Juno Award for Best Alternative Album, and was nominated by the Juno Awards for [[Juno Award for Songwriter of the Year|Best Songwriter]] ("Poses" / "[[Cigarettes and Chocolate Milk]]" / "Grey Gardens").{{Cite news|access-date=November 1, 2008|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0208/17/pitn.00.html|title=CNN Transcripts, CNN People in the News|website=Transcripts.cnn.com|date=August 17, 2002}} From 2001 to 2004, he toured with [[Tori Amos]], [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], [[Ben Folds]], and [[Guster]], as well as headlining the 2001 and 2002 tour in support of the album. Wainwright became addicted to [[Methamphetamine|crystal meth]] in the early 2000s and temporarily lost his vision. His addiction reached its peak in 2002, during what he described as "the most surreal week of my life". During that week, he played a cameo role in the UK comedy television program ''[[Absolutely Fabulous]]'', spent several nights partying with [[George W. Bush]]'s daughter [[Barbara Bush (born 1981)|Barbara]],{{cite web|title=Baroque Pop Idol|work=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]|date=May 14, 2007|access-date=May 14, 2007|url=https://www.motherjones.com/interview/2007/05/rufus_wainwright.html|last=Meredith|first=Peter}} enjoyed a "debauched evening" with his mother and [[Marianne Faithfull]], sang with [[Anohni]] of [[Antony and the Johnsons]] for [[Zaldy]]'s spring 2003 collection, and experienced recurring hallucinations of his father throughout. He decided after that he "was either going to rehab or I was going to live with my father. I knew I needed an asshole to yell at me, and I felt he fit the bill."{{Cite news|title=Crystal clear|work=The Observer |location=UK |date=February 20, 2005| access-date=October 20, 2006|url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/omm/story/0,,1416032,00.html|last=Adams |first=Tim }} ===''Want'' albums=== [[File:Rufus Wainwright.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Wainwright in concert in Chicago]] In 2003, Rufus released the full-length album ''[[Want One]]''.[https://www.allmusic.com/artist/rufus-wainwright-mn0000854854/overview/main#discography Rufus Wainwright discography] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120829142140/http://www.allmusic.com/artist/rufus-wainwright-mn0000854854/overview/main#discography |date=August 29, 2012 }}. [[AllMusic]] Then Wainwright's album ''[[Want Two]]'', from which four songs were released as the EP ''[[Waiting for a Want]]'', was released by [[DreamWorks Pictures|DreamWorks]]/[[Geffen Records|Geffen]] on November 16, 2004. The live [[iTunes]] Sessions [[Extended play|EP]] entitled ''[[Alright, Already: Live in Montréal]]'' was released on March 15, 2005. A DVD entitled ''[[All I Want (Rufus Wainwright DVD)|All I Want]]'', featuring a biographical documentary, music videos, and live performances, was released internationally in 2005. That same year, Wainwright made two major contributions as a solo vocalist to a pair of records: [[Mercury Music Prize|the Mercury Prize]]-winning [[Antony and the Johnsons]]' ''[[I Am a Bird Now|I am a Bird Now]]'' and [[Burt Bacharach]]'s ''[[At This Time]]''. ''Want One'' and ''Want Two'' were repackaged as ''[[Want (Rufus Wainwright album)|Want]]'' for a November 2005 release to coincide with the beginning of a British tour. This version of ''Want One'' contains two extra songs: "Es Muß Sein" and "Velvet Curtain Rag". The ''Want'' package in the UK has two bonus tracks: "Chelsea Hotel No. 2" (a [[Leonard Cohen]] cover) and "In With the Ladies", which replace "Coeur de parisienne – Reprise d'Arletty" and "Quand vous mourez de nos amours" from 2004's augmented edition. ===''Release the Stars'' and ''Rufus Does Judy at Carnegie Hall''=== Wainwright's fifth studio album, ''[[Release the Stars]]'', was released by [[Geffen Records|Geffen]] on May 15, 2007. The album was produced by Wainwright and featured [[Richard Thompson (musician)|Richard Thompson]], friend [[Teddy Thompson]], sister [[Martha Wainwright]], mother [[Kate McGarrigle]], [[Neil Tennant]], [[Joan Wasser]], Julianna Raye, Larry Mullins (professionally known as Toby Dammit), and actress [[Siân Phillips]].{{cite magazine | url=http://www.chartattack.com/news/42967/rufus-wainwright-is-ready-to-release-the-stars | title=Rufus Wainwright is Ready to Release the Stars | access-date=February 26, 2009 | first=Antoinette | last=Mercurio | date=February 13, 2007 | magazine=[[Chart (magazine)|Chartattack.com]] | url-status=dead | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100709160519/http://www.chartattack.com/news/42967/rufus-wainwright-is-ready-to-release-the-stars | archive-date=July 9, 2010 | df=mdy-all }} It reached No.2 on the [[UK Albums Chart]], and debuted at No.23 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. The first single, "[[Going to a Town]]", was released on April 3, 2007 in the [[iTunes Store|iTunes Music Store]]. The second single released was "[[Rules and Regulations (song)|Rules and Regulations]]", and the third single was a 500-copy (12" vinyl) release of "[[Tiergarten (song)|Tiergarten]]", a one-track EP with the Supermayer remix of ''Tiergarten'', which was released exclusively through iTunes and 7digital on October 29. {{Listen |filename=Rufus_Wainright_(2004)_-_On_the_Banks_of_the_Wabash_-_by_Paul_Dresser_(1897).ogg |title=Rufus Wainwright: "Banks of the Wabash" (1997) |description=30 second sample of Rufus Wainwright singing a cover of [[Paul Dresser]]'s "[[On the Banks of the Wabash, Far Away]]" (1897) for the soundtrack to the 1997 film ''[[The Myth of Fingerprints]]''. |format=[[Ogg]]}} Two video clips were released for the album: "Going to a Town", directed by [[Sophie Muller]], and "Rules and Regulations", directed by Petro Papahadjopoulos and styled by J.W. Anderson. ''Release the Stars'' was certified gold in the UK. The accompanying world tour saw Wainwright visit North America, Europe, Asia, and Australia, ending on February 14, 2008 with a concert at the [[Radio City Music Hall]] in New York City. On June 10, 2006, [[National Public Radio|NPR]]'s ''[[Weekend Edition|Weekend Edition Saturday]]'' broadcast an interview of Wainwright by [[Scott Simon]]. The segment concerned Wainwright's sold-out pair of [[Carnegie Hall]] shows on June 14 and 15, 2006 in which he performed the entire [[Judy Garland]] concert album that was recorded there in 1961.{{cite web|first=Richard|last=Cromelin|title=Rufus Wainwright waxing operatic|work=Los Angeles Times|date=May 24, 2007|access-date=May 24, 2007|url=http://www.poststar.com/articles/2007/05/24/go/3cf344000c2bb666852572e4007bdfb6.txt}} He later repeated his performance at the [[London Palladium]], the [[Paris Olympia]], and the [[Hollywood Bowl]] in Los Angeles.{{cite web|title=Rufus Wainwright Brings Judy Garland to Life in Hollywood Bowl Performance|url=http://www.laphil.com/press/press_detail.cfm?id=2077|author=Crane, Adam and Lisa White|publisher=[[Los Angeles Philharmonic]]|access-date=October 9, 2007|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011045351/http://laphil.com/press/press_detail.cfm?id=2077|archive-date=October 11, 2007}} Live CD and DVD recordings of the concerts were released on December 4, 2007. The DVD is entitled ''[[Rufus! Rufus! Rufus! Does Judy! Judy! Judy!: Live from the London Palladium]]''. The CD album, ''[[Rufus Does Judy at Carnegie Hall]]'', is a recording of his show at the New York venue.{{cite web|title=Rufus Wainwright: News & Press|url=http://www.rufuswainwright.com/news/|website=Rufuswainwright.com|access-date=October 9, 2007}} In 2008, Garland's daughter [[Lorna Luft]] expressed strong approval of Wainwright's recordings of her mother's songs.{{cite web|first=Darren|last=Scott|title=Songs my mother taught me|work=The Scotsman |location=UK|date=February 8, 2008|access-date=February 8, 2008|url=http://news.scotsman.com/entertainment/Songs-my-mother-taught-me.3757496.jp}} The album was nominated for a [[51st Grammy Awards|2009]] [[Grammy Award]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Traditional Pop Vocal Album|Best Traditional Pop Vocal Album]].{{cite web|access-date=February 24, 2011|url=https://www2.grammy.com/grammy_Awards/51st_show/list.aspx#03|title=The 51st Annual Grammy Awards Winners List|publisher=[[Grammy Award]]s|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101220105729/http://www2.grammy.com/GRAMMY_Awards/51st_show/list.aspx#03|archive-date=December 20, 2010}} ===Blackoutsabbath and ''Prima Donna''=== [[File:Rufus Wainwright at Met Opera cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|Wainwright in 2008]] Wainwright created the concept of [[Blackoutsabbath]] in early 2008. In an attempt to become more [[Environmentalism|environmentally conscious]], participants are asked to live "[[Off-the-grid|off the grid]]" as much as possible on a designated date by unplugging [[Home appliance|appliances]], [[walking]] or cycling for transportation, turning out lights and [[Energy conservation|decreasing energy usage]] in any other ways possible. As the sun sets on the evening of Blackoutsabbath, participants write ways they can contribute to the [[Earth]]'s well-being throughout the rest of the year. Annual [[benefit concert]]s take place to raise awareness of the cause. Special guests performing at the concert included Joan Wasser, Jenni Muldaur, and friend and fellow singer-songwriter [[Teddy Thompson]].{{cite web|access-date=November 19, 2008|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2008/02/rufus-wainwright-stages-blackoutsabbath-for-june-2.html|work=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|date=February 19, 2008|last=Reidy|first=Julia|title=Rufus Wainwright stages Blackoutsabbath for June 21}} The organization's official site contains updates about the program and contains links to various tools, [[Ethical consumerism|green products and services]], studies, and groups that promote energy conservation and [[environmental protection]].{{cite web|access-date=November 19, 2008|url=http://www.blackoutsabbath.org/links.html|title=Blackoutsabbath Links|publisher=Blackoutsabbath|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090220110337/http://blackoutsabbath.org/links.html|archive-date=February 20, 2009}} In December 2008 Rufus performed alongside his sister, [[Martha Wainwright]], and mother, [[Kate McGarrigle]], as well as many more of his family at the Knitting Factory in downtown Manhattan. Joined by other artists such as [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Lou Reed]] and [[Laurie Anderson]], the cast performed original and traditional Christmas-themed songs. In November 2009 [[Revelation Films]] released the concert on DVD.{{Citation|last1=McGarrigle|first1=Kate|title=A not so silent night: a truly magical Christmas concert|date=2009|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/not-so-silent-night-a-truly-magical-christmas-concert/oclc/939152664|publisher=Revelation Films|language=en|oclc=939152664|access-date=May 16, 2020|last2=McGarrigle|first2=Anna|last3=Wainwright|first3=Rufus|last4=Wainwright|first4=Martha|last5=Schmidt|first5=Gérard}} Following his 2007–2008 tour, Wainwright began writing his first opera, ''[[Prima Donna (opera)|Prima Donna]]'', about "a day in the life of an [[opera singer]]", anxiously preparing for her comeback, who falls in love with a journalist.{{cite web |title=Rueful Rufus: Wainwright savors life's battles|work=[[The Hook (newspaper)|The Hook]]|date=August 9, 2007|access-date=August 9, 2007|url=http://www.readthehook.com/stories/2007/08/09/INTERVIEW-Wainwright-A.rtf.aspx}}{{Cite news|access-date=October 9, 2008|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2008/10/09/bmrufus109.xml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081016171032/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=%2Farts%2F2008%2F10%2F09%2Fbmrufus109.xml|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 16, 2008|work=The Daily Telegraph|location=UK|title=Rufus Wainwright reveals his Wagnerian side|first=Rupert|last=Christiansen|date=October 9, 2008}} There are four [[fictional character|characters]], and the libretto is in French.{{Cite news|first=Bernard|last=Zuel|title=Rufus Wainwright|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=January 25, 2008|access-date=January 29, 2008|url=https://www.smh.com.au/news/gig-reviews/rufus-wainwright/2008/01/25/1201157611129.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap2}} The opera was originally commissioned by [[Metropolitan Opera]] general manager [[Peter Gelb]]. However, because of a dispute over Wainwright's decision to write the libretto in French and the Met's inability to schedule an opening in the 2009 season, Wainwright and the Met ended their relationship.{{Cite news|first=Daniel J.|last=Wakin|title=Pop Singer Drops Plan to Compose for the Met|work=The New York Times |date=August 27, 2008|access-date=February 23, 2011|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/28/arts/music/28rufu.html}} Instead of a New York opening, ''Prima Donna'' was staged during the [[Manchester International Festival]], where the first performance took place at the [[Palace Theatre, Manchester|Palace Theatre]] on July 10, 2009.{{Cite news|first=Randy|last=Lewis|title=Rufus Wainwright and Met Opera part ways|work=Los Angeles Times|date=August 28, 2008|access-date=September 8, 2008|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/soundboard/2008/08/rufus-wainwrigh.html}}{{cite news|access-date=October 9, 2008|url=http://www.gigwise.com/news/46686/Rufus-Wainwright-Opera-Set-For-Manchester-Debut|title=Rufus Wainwright Opera Set For Manchester Debut|last=Gregory|first=Jason|work=[[Gigwise.com]]}} Reviews for the performance were mixed, with one publication suggesting Wainwright "may struggle to convince critics he is worthy of a place among the greats".{{Cite news|first=Mike|last=Collett-White|title=Critics split on Wainwright move from pop to opera|work=Reuters |date=July 13, 2009|access-date=July 13, 2009|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/lifestyleMolt/idUSTRE56C3VU20090713?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0}} ''Prima Donna'' won a [[Dora Mavor Moore Award]] for Outstanding New Musical/Opera in June 2011.{{Cite news|url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/arts/theatre/buddies-in-bad-times-wins-big-at-dora-mavor-moore-awards/article2077750/ |title=Buddies in Bad Times wins big at Dora Mavor Moore Awards |location=Toronto, Canada |work=Globe and Mail |author=J. Kelly Nestruck |date=June 27, 2011 |access-date=September 21, 2011}} ===''All Days Are Nights: Songs for Lulu'' and birth of daughter=== [[File:Rufus Wainright boyfriend Jorn Weisbrodt Shankbone.jpg|thumb|Wainwright and his husband, German arts administrator [[Jörn Weisbrodt]], in 2010.]] In November 2009, Wainwright announced that he had finished recording his sixth studio album, and was calling it ''[[All Days Are Nights: Songs for Lulu]]''.{{cite podcast|url=http://kut.org/items/show/18870 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20120710002010/http://kut.org/items/show/18870 |url-status=dead |archive-date=July 10, 2012 |title=Rufus Wainwright live – November 17, 2009 |website=Kut.org |agency=UT Austin |host=John Aielli |date=November 17, 2009 |access-date=November 25, 2009 }} The album was released on March 23 in Canada, April 5 in the UK and April 20 in the US, with the first single "Who Are You New York?".{{cite podcast | url =http://www.rufuswainwright.com/news/| title =RufusWainwright.com | access-date =July 6, 2010}} In December 2009, Wainwright appeared with sister Martha Wainwright and mother [[Kate McGarrigle]] at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in London, raising $55,000 for the Kate McGarrigle Fund, which was established in 2008 to raise awareness of [[sarcoma]], a rare cancer that affects connective tissue such as bone, muscle, nerves, and cartilage. It was the last performance made by his mother before her death in January 2010. In late 2010 Wainwright became engaged to his partner [[Jörn Weisbrodt]].{{cite magazine |url= https://www.vanityfair.com/online/daily/2010/12/qarufus-wainwright-on |title=Q&A: Rufus Wainwright on Liza, Lulu, and Proposing |author=Jim Windolf |magazine=Vanity Fair |date=December 6, 2010 |access-date=September 27, 2011}} The couple moved to [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] in early 2012 after Weisbrodt was named artistic director of Toronto's annual [[Luminato]] festival.[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/arts/jorn-weisbrodt-named-new-artistic-director-of-luminato/article2175024/ "Jorn Weisbrodt named new artistic director of Luminato"]. ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', September 22, 2011. In 2011, Wainwright announced the birth of his first child, with childhood friend Lorca Cohen, daughter of [[Leonard Cohen]].Michaels, Sean. [https://www.theguardian.com/music/2011/feb/21/rufus-wainwright-baby-with-lorca-cohen “Hallelujah! Rufus Wainwright has baby with Leonard Cohen’s daughter”] ''[[The Guardian]]'', London, February 21, 2011. Retrieved on June 24, 2014. He announced on his website: "Darling daughter Viva Katherine Wainwright Cohen was born on February 2, 2011 in Los Angeles, California to proud parents Lorca Cohen, Rufus Wainwright, and Deputy Dad Jorn Weisbrodt. The little angel is evidently healthy, presumably happy, and certainly very very beautiful."{{cite press release|url=http://www.rufuswainwright.com/news/default.aspx#2b042ae6-9780-44dc-8358-c8e038aa81b6:640386 |title=For Immediate Release |date=February 18, 2011 |publisher=Rufus Wainwright |access-date=February 19, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110222084705/http://www.rufuswainwright.com/news/default.aspx |archive-date=February 22, 2011 }} In July 2011 a 19-disc box set called ''[[House of Rufus]]'' containing all his studio and live recordings as well as previously unreleased material was released.{{cite press release|url=http://www.rufuswainwright.com/news/default.aspx#2b042ae6-9780-44dc-8358-c8e038aa81b6:642474 |title=House Of Rufus Box Set Details Announced, Presale On Now |date=April 11, 2011 |publisher=Rufus Wainwright |access-date=May 25, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525122120/http://www.rufuswainwright.com/news/default.aspx |archive-date=May 25, 2011 }} ===''Out of the Game'' and marriage=== Wainwright recorded his seventh studio album with producer [[Mark Ronson]]. He described the new songs as more "danceable" than his previous material.{{cite web |url= https://www.nme.com/news/rufus-wainwright/56812 |title=Rufus Wainwright working on 'danceable' new album with Mark Ronson |website=[[NME]] |date=May 22, 2011 |access-date=December 2, 2011}} The album, titled ''[[Out of the Game]],'' was released in late April 2012 in the UK and Canada and in early May in the US.{{cite web |url=http://www.musicradar.com/news/guitars/rufus-wainwright-on-working-with-producer-mark-ronson-536103 |title=Rufus Wainwright on working with producer Mark Ronson |date=March 24, 2012 |access-date=March 30, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rufuswainwright.com/news/default.aspx#2b042ae6-9780-44dc-8358-c8e038aa81b6:654045 |title=Pre-Order 'Out of the Game' |date=January 31, 2012 |access-date=March 30, 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325161007/http://www.rufuswainwright.com/news/default.aspx |archive-date=March 25, 2012 }} On August 23, 2012 Rufus Wainwright and [[Jörn Weisbrodt]] married in [[Montauk, New York]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/pagesix/vows_then_clams_oY1n0qt6zBLevJ5FuAOJJK |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130130064135/http://www.nypost.com/p/pagesix/vows_then_clams_oY1n0qt6zBLevJ5FuAOJJK |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 30, 2013 |title=Vows, then clams |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20623459,00.html|title=Rufus Wainwright Weds Jorn Weisbrodt|date=August 24, 2012|access-date=August 26, 2012}} ===Second opera=== His second opera, called Cincinnati College-Conservatory of Music]], before its premiere.{{Cite news|url=http://www.citybeat.com/arts-culture/arts-desk/article/20972673/rufus-wainwright-to-bring-his-operainprogress-here|title=Rufus Wainwright set to bring his opera-in-progress here|last=Arenstein|first=Anne|date=August 15, 2017|work=CityBeat Cincinnati|access-date=September 13, 2017|language=en}} === ''Prima Donna'''s revival === {{Main|Prima Donna: A Symphonic Visual Concert}} In 2015, Wainwright launched a new version of his first opera, accompanied by a film directed by [[Francesco Vezzoli]], featuring [[Cindy Sherman]] as the Prima Donna.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/culture/2015/04/prima-donna-opera-new-video-rufus-wainwright|title=Rufus Wainwright's New Video Installation for Prima Donna – Vanity Fair|author=Derek Blasberg|magazine=Vanity Fair|date=April 24, 2015|access-date=April 22, 2016}} The finale was shot in Paris during spring 2015 and produced by Petite Maison Production,{{cite web|url=http://www.petitemaisonproduction.com/PETITE_MAISON_PRODUCTION_US/PRIMA_DONNA_US.html|title=PRIMA DONNA US|website=Petitemaisonproduction.com|access-date=April 22, 2016|archive-date=March 3, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303184128/http://www.petitemaisonproduction.com/PETITE_MAISON_PRODUCTION_US/PRIMA_DONNA_US.html|url-status=dead}} before it premiered in Athens{{cite web|url=http://greekfestival.gr/en/events/view/rufus-wainwright-2015|title=Rufus Wainwright – Athens & Epidaurus Festival 2015|work=Athens & Epidaurus Festival 2015|access-date=April 22, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117031354/http://greekfestival.gr/en/events/view/rufus-wainwright-2015|archive-date=November 17, 2015|url-status=dead}} in September. ===''Unfollow the Rules''=== Almost a year after releasing stand-alone single [[Sword of Damocles (Rufus Wainwright song)|"Sword of Damocles"]] in October 2018, Rufus signed a record deal with music publisher and record label [[BMG Rights Management]] for a new album.{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/record-labels/8533103/rufus-wainwright-bmg-record-deal|title=Rufus Wainwright Signs Record Deal With BMG for New Album|website=Billboard.com|date=October 16, 2019}} Soon after, new song [[Trouble in Paradise (Rufus Wainwright song)|"Trouble in Paradise"]] was released as the first single from the album. In February 2020, the album, ''[[Unfollow the Rules]]'', was announced alongside the release of [[Joni Mitchell]] inspired single [[Damsel in Distress (song)|"Damsel in Distress"]]{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/rufus-wainwright-pays-homage-to-joni-mitchell-on-new-single-damsel-in-distress-2615633|title=Rufus Wainwright pays homage to Joni Mitchell on new single, 'Damsel In Distress'|website=Nme.com|date=February 27, 2020}} and was slated for an April release. A third single, [[Peaceful Afternoon (Rufus Wainwright song)|"Peaceful Afternoon"]], was released on digital platforms in March, with a French version, Pièce à vivre, as a B-side. In early April, the album release was delayed until July after escalation of the [[COVID-19 pandemic]], Wainwright stating that "The CD's and vinyl LP's of my new album Unfollow The Rules are stuck in the warehouses they had to shut down to make way for all essential businesses being able to operate at full speed", adding "You know that I am an old school guy and for me the physical product is extremely important. I am incredibly proud of this album and the way I want you to experience it ideally is listening to it from front to back in the comfort of your living room, reading the lyrics, and looking at the booklet that I carefully designed."{{cite web|url=https://www.thelineofbestfit.com/news/latest-news/rufus-wainwright-delays-new-album-until-july-due-to-coronavirus|title=Rufus Wainwright delays new album until July due to coronavirus|website=Thelineofbestfit.com}} This announcement was accompanied by the announcement of a fourth single, [[Alone Time (Rufus Wainwright song)|"Alone Time"]], which was released on the April 24, 2020, the date the LP was originally due to be released. One more single, a [[tongue-in-cheek]] commentary on fame and status relative to geographic location entitled [[You Ain't Big (Rufus Wainwright song)|"You Ain't Big"]], was released in early June.{{cite web|url=https://www.thelineofbestfit.com/news/latest-news/rufus-wainwright-unveils-new-single-you-aint-big|title=Rufus Wainwright unveils new single "You Ain't Big"s|website=Thelineofbestfit.com}} On July 10, Rufus Wainwright's 10th studio album, ''[[Unfollow the Rules]]'', was released. The album was met with a warm reception upon release and has amassed mostly positive critic reviews, with an aggregate score of 82 on [[Metacritic]], which is his highest score on the site equal only to his 2001 LP [[Poses (album)|''Poses'']].{{cite web|url=https://www.metacritic.com/music/unfollow-the-rules/rufus-wainwright|title=Rufus Wainwright: Unfollow the Rules|website=Metacritic.com}} ==Artistry== In addition to his [[tenor]]{{cite web|last=Kaliss |first=Jeff |url=http://www.sfcv.org/events-calendar/artist-spotlight/rufus-wainwright-dons-classical-drag |title=Rufus Wainwright Dons Classical Drag : San Francisco Classical Voice |website=Sfcv.org |access-date=February 28, 2012}} singing voice, Wainwright plays piano and guitar, often switching between the two instruments when performing live. While some songs feature just Wainwright and his piano, his later work is often accompanied by rock instrumentation or a symphony orchestra, displaying complex layering and [[harmony|harmonies]] with an operatic feel. Wainwright is an opera enthusiast{{cite web |url=http://www.rufuswainwright.com/bio/ |title=Rufus Wainwright Biography |website=Rufuswainwright.com |access-date=February 28, 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225184314/http://www.rufuswainwright.com/bio/ |archive-date=February 25, 2012 }} and likes [[Franz Schubert]]'s ''[[lieder]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.imeem.com/groups/UhsRfQeA,rufus-wainwright-beautiful-voice/ |title=The Rufus Wainwright beautiful voice Group |website=Imeem.com |access-date=February 28, 2012}} Wainwright's music has been described as "[[popera]]" (pop opera) or "[[baroque pop]]". Many of his compositions are densely packed amalgams of strings, horns, operatic choruses, and ragtime rhythms, with a warm vocal timbre.{{cite web|first=David|last=Sason|title=Busting at the Seams|website=Metroactive.com|date=July 25, 2007|access-date=January 29, 2008 |url=http://www.metroactive.com/bohemian/07.25.07/rufus-wainwright-0730.html}} He often performs with his sister, Martha Wainwright, on backup vocals. Despite critical acclaim, Wainwright has experienced limited commercial success in the United States, although the release of ''Release the Stars'' saw increased media attention there, as did the associated 2007 U.S. tour.{{Cite news|title=The Superfabulous World of Rufus Wainwright|work=The New York Times|date=June 4, 2007|access-date=June 6, 2007 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/04/arts/music/04wain.html?ref=arts | first=Melena | last=Ryzik}} ===Themes=== Wainwright's work contains several recurring themes: opera, literature, pop culture, politics, and love (often [[unrequited love]]). "Foolish Love" and "Danny Boy" are about a crush he once had on a straight man.''There Will Be Rainbows'', page 72 Other songs address full-blown love and the consequences of falling out of love ("This Love Affair", "Leaving for Paris", and "Peach Trees"). Wainwright also sings about his family relationships. "Beauty Mark", "Little Sister" and "Martha", and "[[Dinner at Eight (song)|Dinner at Eight]]" address, respectively, his experiences with his mother, sisters, and father. Several songs deal with his experiences with addiction ("Go Or Go Ahead" and "[[I Don't Know What It Is]]").{{citation needed|date=February 2019}} The song "Matinee Idol" was written about [[River Phoenix]].''There Will Be Rainbows'', page 73 "Memphis Skyline" is a tribute to the late singer [[Jeff Buckley]], whom he met briefly in the 1990s when Wainwright was an up-and-coming act. By this time, Buckley had already released his first album ''[[Grace (Jeff Buckley album)|Grace]]'', and was well on his way to stardom. The two met several months prior to Buckley's drowning, during a gig by Wainwright. The song references "[[Hallelujah (Leonard Cohen song)|Hallelujah]]", a [[Leonard Cohen]] song covered by Buckley (and later by Wainwright).''There Will Be Rainbows'', page 97 "Nobody's Off the Hook" is written to close friend and fellow musician [[Teddy Thompson]].''There Will Be Rainbows'', page 246 ===Legacy=== Wainwright and his music have influenced several artists in the music industry. They include [[Katy Perry]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/en_uk/article/aevxd8/a-deep-dive-into-katy-perrys-2007-myspace-page|title=A Deep Dive into Katy Perry's 2007 Myspace Page|website=Vice.com|date=January 10, 2017|access-date=July 11, 2020}} [[Olly Alexander]] of [[Years & Years]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/pg7jm8/the-new-british-invasion-how-gay-pop-stars-are-winning-over-america|title=The New British Invasion: How Gay Pop Stars Are Winning over America|date=April 28, 2016}} Liv Bruce of [[Pwr Bttm]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/magazine-feature/7717061/pwr-bttm-rufus-wainwright-interview|title=PWR BTTM & Rufus Wainwright Talk Sexuality, Trump & 'The Future of Diversity In Music'|date=March 9, 2017|website=Billboard.com|access-date=July 11, 2020}} and [[Kimbra]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.out.com/entertainment/music/2012/06/07/kimbra-album-vows-settle-down-gotye?amp|format=JPG|title=Catching Up With Kimbra|website=Out.com|date=June 7, 2012 |access-date=June 7, 2012}} In [[Nick Hornby]]'s book ''[[Slam (novel)|Slam]]'', the child born to the young protagonists gets called "Rufus" because his mother listened to Rufus Wainwright while recovering from the ordeal of giving birth.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/11/books/review/Garner-t.html|title=Knocked Up|first=Dwight|last=Garner|date=November 11, 2007|website=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=July 11, 2020}} ==Personal life== Wainwright married German art administrator [[Jörn Weisbrodt]] on August 23, 2012.{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/amp/life/homes/decor/2013/03/01/rufus_plus_jrn_equals_a_happy_home.html|title=A peek inside Rufus Wainwright and Jörn Weisbrodt's Annex home|last=Zekas|first=Rita|date=March 1, 2013|website=The Star|access-date=October 25, 2019}} Wainwright has a daughter, Viva Katherine Wainwright Cohen, born February 2, 2011, conceived via [[sperm donation]] by Wainwright to Lorca Cohen, daughter of [[Leonard Cohen]]. She lives with her mother.{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/amp/life/homes/decor/2013/03/01/rufus_plus_jrn_equals_a_happy_home.html|title=A peek inside Rufus Wainwright and Jörn Weisbrodt's Annex home {{!}} The Star|website=www.thestar.com|access-date=October 25, 2019}} ===Political views=== Wainwright identifies as "a complete [[Libertarianism|libertarian]]" and stated in 2008, "I don't think any government should encroach on what goes on in the bedroom at all."{{cite web |url=http://www.nypress.com/blog-3026-messiahs-gay-and-otherwise-a-very-rufus-wainwright.html |title=Messiahs, Gay and Otherwise: A Very Rufus Wainwright Christmas |author=Andy Seccombe |date=December 8, 2008 |work=New York Press |access-date=November 21, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091214172716/http://www.nypress.com/blog-3026-messiahs-gay-and-otherwise-a-very-rufus-wainwright.html |archive-date=December 14, 2009 }} In April 2010, Wainwright came out publicly in favour of legalizing [[same-sex marriage]] in the United States because he wanted to marry Weisbrodt. Wainwright stated, "I wasn't a huge gay marriage supporter before I met Jörn because I love the whole old-school promiscuous [[Oscar Wilde]] freak show of what 'being gay' once was. But since meeting Jörn that all changed."{{cite web |url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2010/04/02/rufus_wainwright_wants_to_marry_his_pa |title=Rufus Wainwright Wants To Marry His Partner |date=April 2, 2010 |website=Starpulse.com |access-date=April 2, 2010}} Wainwright has publicly opposed 45th US President [[Donald Trump]], addressing him in the music video for his song "[[Sword of Damocles (Rufus Wainwright song)|Sword of Damocles]]" in 2018{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wmUVy43tqw4 | archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211107/wmUVy43tqw4| archive-date=2021-11-07 | url-status=live|title=Rufus Wainwright - Sword of Damocles (Official Music Video)|via=[[YouTube]] |date=October 31, 2018}}{{cbignore}} and stating "It's impossible to minimise the ineptitude and pure evil of the Trump administration" in a 2020 interview with ''NME''.{{cite web |url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/rufus-wainwright-its-impossible-to-minimise-the-ineptitude-and-pure-evil-of-the-trump-administration-2704633 |title=Rufus Wainwright: "It's impossible to minimise the ineptitude and pure evil of the Trump administration" |website=[[NME]] |date=July 9, 2020}} ==Work in film, television, and theatre== [[File:Rufus Wainwright Sundance.jpg|thumb|upright|Wainwright at the [[Sundance Film Festival]] in 2006]] Wainwright has appeared in the films ''[[The Aviator (2004 film)|The Aviator]]'' and ''[[Heights (film)|Heights]]'' in addition to his role in ''[[Tommy Tricker and the Stamp Traveller]]'' but said in a 2010 interview "I definitely enjoy seeing myself thirty feet high, but it's not something that I'm running toward passionately".{{cite web|last=Needles|first=Tim|title=The Rufus Wainwright Interview|url=http://www.shortandsweetnyc.com/2010/08/the-rufus-wainwright-interview/|work=Short and Sweet NYC|access-date=January 21, 2012}} He has also recorded tracks specially for films, including ''[[Brokeback Mountain]]'', ''[[I Am Sam|I am Sam]]'', ''[[Moulin Rouge!]]'', ''[[Shrek]]'', ''[[Meet the Robinsons]]'', ''[[Big Daddy (1999 film)|Big Daddy]]'', ''[[Zoolander]]'', and ''[[Leonard Cohen: I'm Your Man]]''. His recording of "[[Bewitched, Bothered, and Bewildered]]" plays during the closing credits of the film ''[[The History Boys (film)|The History Boys]]''. He is seen in the [[Denys Arcand]] film ''[[Days of Darkness (2007 Canadian film)|Days of Darkness]] (L'Âge des ténèbres)'', performing two [[aria]]s. The ''[[All I Want (Rufus Wainwright DVD)|All I Want]]'' DVD, released in 2005, features a full-length documentary (''A Portrait of Rufus Wainwright''), performances at Central Park [[Summerstage|SummerStage]] and [[Cambridge Corn Exchange]], studio sessions, music videos, and two bonus [[Easter egg (media)|Easter egg]]s: a 12-minute documentary from 1998, featuring Wainwright and his family, and a short tribute to the [[Kate and Anna McGarrigle|McGarrigle sisters]] featuring Rufus and Martha. In February 2005, the [[Pennsylvania Ballet]] premiered a ballet by Matthew Neenan that was set to Wainwright's music.{{cite web|first= Lori|last=Ibay|title=Pennsylvania Ballet|work=Ballet-Dance|url=http://www.ballet-dance.com/200503/articles/PAB20050202a.html|date=March 2005|access-date=October 19, 2008}} The Pennsylvania Ballet has performed the work (titled ''11:11'') several times, including during an eponymous program in June 2006.{{cite web|first=Lori|last=Ibay|title= Pennsylvania Ballet|work=Ballet-Dance|url=http://www.ballet-dance.com/200608/articles/PAB20060609.html|date=August 2006|access-date=October 19, 2008}} It has been an audience favorite, although critical reviews have been mixed.{{Cite news|first=John|last=Rockwell|title=Pop Tunes and Idioms, a Classical Vocabulary|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/02/04/arts/dance/04nine.html|date=February 4, 2005|access-date=October 19, 2008}} [[Stephen Petronio]] commissioned Wainwright to write a score for his dance production ''BLOOM'', which was performed at Joyce Theater in New York in April 2006. For the lyrics, the two selected poems by [[Walt Whitman]] and [[Emily Dickinson]], and Petronio arranged for the Young People's Choir of New York to sing them.{{cite news |author=Valerie Gladstone |title=A choreographer challenges dancers, tastes, and himself |url=https://www.boston.com/news/globe/living/articles/2007/01/12/a_choreographer_challenges_dancers_tastes_and_himself/ |date=January 12, 2007 |work=Globe Correspondent |publisher=Globe Newspaper Company |access-date=September 14, 2009}} In May 2006, Wainwright was one of three guests (along with [[Robbie Williams]] and [[Frances Barber]]) to star with the [[Pet Shop Boys]] in a concert at London's [[Mermaid Theatre]]. He covered the Pet Shop Boys' "Casanova in Hell" (from ''[[Fundamental (Pet Shop Boys album)|Fundamental]]''). The critically acclaimed show was broadcast on the UK's [[BBC Radio 2]] and repeated on [[BBC 6 Music]], and released as a CD (''[[Concrete (Pet Shop Boys album)|Concrete]]'') in October 2006. In June 2007, Wainwright was a part of the multi-artist [[True Colors Tour 2007|True Colors Tour]], which traveled through 15 cities in the United States and Canada. The tour, sponsored by the [[Logo (TV channel)|Logo]] channel, began on June 8, 2007. Hosted by comedian [[Margaret Cho]] and headlined by [[Cyndi Lauper]], the tour included [[Debbie Harry]], [[The Gossip]], the [[Indigo Girls]], [[The Dresden Dolls]], [[The MisShapes]], and [[Erasure]]. Profits went to the [[Human Rights Campaign]]. In August 2007, Wainwright said that he considered it a "great honor" to perform on the gay rights tour.{{cite web|first= Sarah|last=Rodman|title=With 'Stars' in his eyes, Wainwright keeps busy|work=The Boston Globe|date=August 19, 2007|access-date=August 22, 2007|url=https://www.boston.com/ae/music/articles/2007/08/19/with_stars_in_his_eyes_wainwright_keeps_busy/}} Wainwright continued to tour during 2007 and embraced forms of expression not usually part of mainstream American music concerts. These included dressing in red lipstick and stiletto heeled shoes to perform [[Judy Garland]] songs, and expressing his concerns against the current U.S. political situation. His performances were critically acclaimed.{{cite web|first=Izzi|last=Bendall|title=Wainwright show revives old Hollywood|work=Flint Journal Review|date=August 26, 2007|access-date=August 27, 2007|url=http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/fljournal/index.ssf?/base/features-2/1188132628267570.xml&coll=5 |archive-url = https://archive.today/20070930182700/http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/fljournal/index.ssf?/base/features-2/1188132628267570.xml&coll=5 |archive-date = September 30, 2007}} In April 2009, Wainwright worked with the [[Berliner Ensemble]] and the [[avant-garde]] director [[Robert Wilson (director)|Robert Wilson]], who hired Wainwright to supply the music for a joint staging of ''Shakespeares Sonette'' based on [[Shakespeare's sonnets]].{{cite web |author=Wolfgang Höbel |title=Rufus Wainwright Takes Residency at Brecht's Theater |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/zeitgeist/0,1518,617273,00.html |date=April 3, 2009|work=Der Spiegel |access-date=September 14, 2009}} In June 2012, Wainwright released a comedy video on the [[Funny or Die]] website, giving his interpretation of a number of jingles from chewing gum commercials.{{cite web|last=Funny or Die|title=Rufus Does Gum!|date=June 11, 2012|url=http://www.funnyordie.com/videos/658f52fdb0/rufus-does-gum|access-date=March 3, 2013}} Also in 2012, Wainwright wrote and sang "Metaphorical Blanket" in the film ''[[Any Day Now (2012 At the age of 15, in 1989, he was nominated for a [[Genie Award]] for ''Best Original Song''.{{cite web |url=http://www.academy.ca/hist/history.cfm?categid=17&shownum=10&winonly=0&awards=1&rtype=5&curstep=4 |title=10th Genies: Best Original Song nominees |work=academy.ca |year=1989 |access-date=September 27, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061010105252/http://www.academy.ca/hist/history.cfm?categid=17&shownum=10&winonly=0&awards=1&rtype=5&curstep=4 |archive-date=October 10, 2006 }} A year later he received a nomination for a Juno Award for ''Most Promising Male Vocalist''.
